case_name: Nar Singh and Roshan Singh v. State

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 4 of 1952 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 4 of 1952.

facts.text: Appeal under Article 134(1)(c) of the Constitution of India.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal under Article 134 1  c  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order dated the 7th May, 1951,

facts.text: High Court of Judicature at Allahabad delivered Judgment and Order dated 7th May 1951 in Criminal Appeal No. 350 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: from the Judgment and Order dated the 7th May, 1951, of the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad in Criminal Appeal No. 350 of 1950 arising out of the Judgment

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge, Etah delivered Judgment and Order dated 9th March 1950 in Sessions Trials Nos. 127 of 1949 and 10 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the Judgment and Order dated the 9th March, 1950, of the Court of the Additional Sessions Judge, Etah in Sessions Trials Nos. 127 of 1949 and 10 of 1950.

facts.text: P. Verma appeared for the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: P. Verma for the appellant.

facts.text: P. Lal appeared for the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: P. Lal for the respondent.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on May 5, 1954 by BOSE J.

anchor.surface_text: 1954. May 5. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BOSE J.-

facts.text: Twenty-four persons, including the two appellants, were tried for offences under sections 148, 307/149 and 302/149, Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BOSE J.-Twenty-four persons, among them the two appellants, were tried for offences under sections 148, 307/149 and 302/149, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Sixteen persons were acquitted at trial.

anchor.surface_text: Sixteen were acquitted and the remainmg eight were companyvicted.

facts.text: Eight persons were convicted at trial.

anchor.surface_text: the remainmg eight were companyvicted. On appeal to the High Court five more were acquitted

facts.text: On appeal to High Court, five more were acquitted.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal to the High Court five more were acquitted and the only ones whose companyvictions were upheld

facts.text: High Court upheld convictions of Nar Singh, Roshan Singh, and Nanhu Singh.

anchor.surface_text: and the only ones whose companyvictions were upheld were the two appellants, Nar Singh and Roshan Singh, and one Nanhu Singh.

facts.text: High Court misread evidence and mixed up Nanhu Singh with Bechan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: By a curious misreading of the evidence this Nanhu Singh was mixed up with Bechan Singh.

facts.text: High Court acquitted Bechan Singh and convicted Nanhu Singh by mistake.

anchor.surface_text: What the High Court really meant to do was to companyvict Bechan Singh and acquit Nanhu Singh. Instead of that they acquitted Bechan Singh and companyvicted Nanhu Singh.

facts.text: High Court Judges realised mistake and communicated with State Government.

anchor.surface_text: As soon as the learned High Court Judges realised their mistake they companymunicated with the State Government

facts.text: State Government remitted sentence of Nanhu Singh and directed his release.

anchor.surface_text: and an order was thereupon passed by that Government remitting the sentence mistakenly Passed on Nanhu and directing that he be released.

facts.text: Nanhu Singh, Nar Singh and Roshan Singh applied for certificate under Article 134(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: This occasioned an application under article 134 1   c  of the Constitution by Nanhu Singh and the two appellants Nar Singh and Roshan Singh for a certificate.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate to Nanhu Singh, Nar Singh and Roshan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rightly companysidered that the certificate should issue in the case of Nanhu Singh... As regards the other two...

facts.text: Nanhu Singh did not appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Having obtained the certificate Nanhu did number appeal and the only ones who have companye up here are the two companyvicts.

facts.text: Nar Singh and Roshan Singh appealed to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: and the only ones who have companye up here are the two companyvicts.

facts.text: A number of persons joined in an attack at two in the morning on helpless persons who were asleep in bed.

anchor.surface_text: A number of persons joined in an attack at two in the morning on helpless persons who were asleep in bed.

facts.text: High Court found there were more than five persons involved.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court gives a clear finding that there were more than five persons and believes the eye- witnesses who identify the two appellants.

facts.text: Eye-witnesses identified the two appellants.

anchor.surface_text: believes the eye- witnesses who identify the two appellants. The mere fact that only two out of the band of attackers were satisfactorily identified

facts.text: Supreme Court treated the case as one under Article 136(1) for special leave.

anchor.surface_text: We hold therefore that the certificate was wrongly granted to the appellants and will treat their case as one under article 136 1  for special leave.

facts.text: Supreme Court found no reason to interfere with the convictions and sentences.

anchor.surface_text: The use of section 149, Indian Penal Code, was therefore justified and the companyvictions are proper. We see numberreason to interfere with the sentences.

anchor.surface_text: In the case of clause  c  both of article 133 1  and article 134 1 , the only condition is the discretion of the High Court but the discretion is a judicial one and must be judicially exercised along the well established lines which govern these matters  see Banarsi Parshad v. arguments.claim: 'Case' in Article 134(1)(c) means the case of each individual person, particularly on appeal where each convict's case is separate.

anchor.surface_text: Case as used there means the case of each individual person. That would be so even if the trial had been by the High Court itself but it is even more so on appeal because, though several persons may join in presenting a companymon memorandum of appeal  if the Rules of the Court in question so permit , the appeal of each forms a separate case for those purposes.

arguments.claim: Supreme Court can review whether certificate under Art 134(1)(c) rightly granted, as mere grant does not preclude determination.

anchor.surface_text: Article 134 1   c  uses the same language as article 133 1   c . A certificate is, required under article 133 1 . in each of the four cases set out there but the mere grant of the certificate would not preclude this Court from determining whether it was rightly granted

arguments.claim: Discretion under Art 134(1)(c) is judicial, must be exercised along established lines, and reviewable if misdirected or fettered.

anchor.surface_text: In the case of clause  c  both of article 133 1  and article 134 1 , the only condition is the discretion of the High Court but the discretion is a judicial one and must be judicially exercised along the well established lines which govern these matters  see Banarsi Parshad v. Kashi Krishna  2  also the certificate must show on the face of it that the discretion conferred was invoked and exercised Radhakrishna Ayyar v. Swaminatha Ayyar  3  and Radha Krishn Das v. Rai Krishn Chand  4 .

arguments.claim: High Court misdirected itself on law, fettered discretion by thinking no option to refuse certificate to appellants.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the learned High Court Judges thought they had nooption. They misdirected themselves about the law and as a consequence did not exercise the discretion which is vested in them. They are quite clear as to what they would have done if, in their judgment, the law had left them scope for the exercise of any discretion, for they say- Ordinarily no certificate can be granted to them as there is nothing of an exceptional nature in their cases.

arguments.claim: Certificate under Art 134(1)(c) wrongly granted to appellants; treat case as petition for special leave under Art 136(1).

anchor.surface_text: We hold therefore that the certificate was wrongly granted to the appellants and will treat their case as one under article 136 1  for special leave.

arguments.claim: Not proper case for special leave under Art 136(1) given High Court's clear findings on more than five persons and credible eye-witness identification.

anchor.surface_text: Regarded from that angle, this is not a proper case for special leave. The High Court gives a clear finding that there were more than five persons and believes the eye- witnesses who identify the two appellants.

arguments.claim: Section 149 IPC applies as more than five persons involved, even if only two appellants satisfactorily identified.

anchor.surface_text: The mere fact that only two out of the band of attackers were satisfactorily identified does not weaken the force of the finding that more than five were involved. The use of section 149, Indian Penal Code, was therefore justified and the convictions are proper. We see no reason to interfere with the sentences.

holdings.text: Case as used there means the case of each individual person. That would be so even if the trial had been by the High Court itself but it is even more so on appeal because, though several persons may join in presenting a common memorandum of appeal, the appeal of each forms a separate case for those purposes.

anchor.surface_text: Case as used there means the case of each individual person. That would be so even if the trial had been by the High Court itself but it is even more so on appeal because, though several persons may join in presenting a common memorandum of appeal , the appeal of each forms a separate case for those purposes.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred in treating 'case' as the entire appeal; textually and purposively, it refers to each individual's case, especially on appeal where appeals are separate despite joint memorandum.

holdings.text: This Court [Supreme Court] is not precluded from determining whether [Article 134(1)(c)] certificate was rightly granted and whether conditions prerequisite to the grant are satisfied.

anchor.surface_text: Article 134 1   c  uses the same language as article 133 1   c . A certificate is, required under article 133 1 . in each of the four cases set out there but the mere grant of the certificate would not preclude this Court from determining whether it was rightly granted

holdings.reasoning_summary: Similar language in Art 133(1)(c); mere grant does not bind Supreme Court; judicial superintendence and duty to interpret Constitution allow review.

holdings.text: In the case of clause (c) both of article 133(1) and article 134(1), the only condition is the discretion of the High Court but the discretion is a judicial one and must be judicially exercised along the well established lines which govern these matters.

Rai Krishn Chand  4 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Judicial discretion must follow precedents like Banarsi Parshad; certificate must show exercise of discretion; reviewable if misdirected.

holdings.text: The learned High Court Judges thought they had no option. They misdirected themselves about the law and as a consequence did not exercise the discretion which is vested in them.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the learned High Court Judges thought they had nooption. holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court fettered discretion by wrongly believing bound to grant certificate to all; admitted no exceptional nature in appellants' cases.

holdings.text: We hold therefore that the certificate was wrongly granted to the appellants and will treat their case as one under article 136(1) for special leave.

anchor.surface_text: We hold therefore that the certificate was wrongly granted to the appellants and will treat their case as one under article 136 1  for special leave.

holdings.text: The mere fact that only two out of the band of attackers were satisfactorily identified does not weaken the force of the finding that more than five were involved. anchor.surface_text: The mere fact that only two out of the band of attackers were satisfactorily identified does not weaken the force of the finding that more than five were involved. holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court found >5 persons; partial identification does not negate unlawful assembly; S.149 IPC applies to hold members liable.

anchor.surface_text: Case as used there means the case of each individual person. That would be so even if the trial had been by the High Court itself but it is even more so on appeal because, though several persons may join in presenting a common memorandum of appeal , the appeal of each forms a separate case for those purposes.

We hold therefore that the certificate was wrongly granted to the appellants and will treat their case as one under article 136 1  for special leave. Regarded from that angle, this is number a proper case for special leave. The High Court gives a clear finding that there were more than five persons and believes the eye- witnesses who identify the two appellants. The mere fact that only two out

Rai Krishn Chand  4 .

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the learned High Court Judges thought they had nooption. They misdirected themselves about the law and as a consequence did not exercise the discretion which is vested in them. They are quite clear as to what they would have done if, in their judgment, the law had left them scope for the exercise of any discretion, for they say- Ordinarily no certificate can be granted to them as there is nothing of an exceptional nature in their cases.

We hold therefore that the certificate was wrongly granted to the appellants and will treat their case as one under article 136 1  for special leave. Regarded from that angle, this is number a proper case for special leave. The High Court gives a clear finding that there were more than five persons and believes the eye- witnesses who identify the two appellants. The mere fact that only two out

edges.explanation: The holding text directly responds to the issue by stating that identification of only two attackers does not undermine the finding of more than five involved and justifies the use of Section 149 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The mere fact that only two out of the band of attackers were satisfactorily identified does not weaken the force of the finding that more than five were involved. The use of section 149, Indian Penal Code, was therefore justified and the convictions are proper. We see no reason to interfere with the sentences.

We hold therefore that the certificate was wrongly granted to the appellants and will treat their case as one under article 136 1  for special leave. Regarded from that angle, this is number a proper case for special leave. The High Court gives a clear finding that there were more than five persons and believes the eye- witnesses who identify the two appellants. The mere fact that only two out

edges.explanation: Holding h8 explicitly states that the Federal Court judgment under section 205 of Government of India Act, 1935 cannot be applied, directly addressing issue i6

anchor.surface_text: Reliance was placed on a decision of the Federal Court reported in Subhanand Chowdhary v. Apurba Krishna Mitra 1 . We do not think the judgment of the Federal Court can be applied to this case. It deals with section 205 of the Government of India Act, 1935, covering a different subject and does not use the same or similar words.

We hold therefore that the certificate was wrongly granted to the appellants and will treat their case as one under article 136 1  for special leave. Regarded from that angle, this is number a proper case for special leave. The High Court gives a clear finding that there were more than five persons and believes the eye- witnesses who identify the two appellants. The mere fact that only two out
